OVERVIEW

Air Liquide Large Industries (Air Liquide) Freeport hydrogen and carbon monoxide HYCO facility is covered by EPA's accidental release prevention program regulations and is subject to OSHA's process safety management (PSM) standard.   The Air Liquide HYCO facility's flammable syngas process is closely monitored and controlled to prevent accidental releases to prevent unnecessary human and environmental exposure and to reduce the potential threat to personnel and nearby members of the community.  Air Liquide's policy is to comply with all applicable federal and state rules and regulations. 



REGULATED CHEMICAL

The plant's steam methane reforming process design basis is to provide a safe, clean and efficient way to produce high purity syngas using natural gas and steam methane as feedstock.  The purified gases are sold to Industrial customer(s). The plant also produces steam and electricity for sales to its customers. The plant is designed for continuous operation and is designed for inherently safe operation.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION STEPS

The summary below discusses the process safety system in place to implement the accidental release prevention program.



The Freeport HYCO process equipment meets or exceeds design codes and standards.  The equipment was designed by engineers. Documentation pertaining to the design of the process equipment is maintained. 

Process hazard analysis by HAZOP has been used to identify potential concerns and ensure  mitigation to low levels of risk per Air Liquide policy.

Written procedures have been developed to address various modes of process operations, such as (1) unit initial startup; (2) unit normal and temporary operations; (3) unit shutdown; (4) emergency shutdown; (5) startup following an emergency shutdown; and (6) process deviation, consequence and action.  These procedures are reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate.

Personnel  involved in operating and maintaining the syngas

process receive a combination of classroom, computer-based (CBT) and hands-on training that addresses: process hazards and health & safety orientation, site rules and practices, process safety information, normal and emergency operating procedures, the use of safety procedures and equipment, incident investigation and emergency action.  

Air Liquide has established a mechanical integrity (MI) program and procedures to maintain the pressure vessels, piping systems, relief valves, rotating equipment, process control and emergency shutdown systems. 

Management of change is used for any alterations to the covered process and a pre-startup review occurs prior to startup associated with any significant change.

Risk Management Plan program audits are conducted on a reoccuring 3 year basis .

Should there be a process safety event an incident investigation process is applied to ensure root causes, contributing factors and recommendations are identified to mitigate future risk of  future occurrence.

Plant personnel are expected to participate in accidental release prevention program (PSM/RMP).   Employees take part in process hazard analysis and are trained on and are provided access to the Freeport HYCO syngas process safety information.

Air Liquide has put in place a safe and hot work permitting system to help ensure worker and process safety can be maintained. This system addresses energy control and isolation, process (line) break, hot work, and confined space entry. 

Where contractors are used to support the covered process the contractors must first undergo a pre qualification selection and then planned periodic monitoring process.  Individual contractor employees must attend annual site specific safety training.

 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE

Air Liquide Freeport HYCO facility has developed a comprehensive Emergency Action Plan (EAP). In the event of an accidental injury, fire and/or a process release .   The Emergency Action Plan (EAP) is coordinated with Freeport HYC

O's designated emergency responder, the Freeport Dow Chemical emergency response team (ERT). The Freeport HYCO EAP  includes information for notifying the Dow ERT, the Freeport Police, & Emergency Medical Services as well as other State and Federal agencies.   Air Liquide plant personnel routinely review and  training on the plan.  Emergency Drills are conducted annually.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no accidents or incidents with catastrophic consequences at this site since its commission.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Air Liquide Freeport HYCO resolves all findings of its PHA and other hazard reviews some of which result in modifications of the process. For example plant has in the prior 5 years upgraded the process distributed control system (DCS) software and the plant area monitoring system with new carbon monoxide sensors and light and heat sensing cameras .
